storyTitle: As Scheduler, I want the system to detect scheduling conflicts within 2 seconds to enable immediate action

testCases.title: Verify conflict detection within 2 seconds
preconditions: User is logged in with Scheduler role
Scheduling system is operational and accessible
At least one existing booking is present in the system
System clock is synchronized
Conflict detection service is running

steps.action: Navigate to the scheduling interface and note the current timestamp
steps.expectedResult: Scheduling interface loads successfully with booking creation form displayed

steps.action: Create a new booking entry that overlaps with an existing booking (same resource, overlapping time slot)
steps.expectedResult: Booking submission is processed and conflict detection is triggered

steps.action: Record the timestamp when conflict notification appears and calculate the time difference from submission
steps.expectedResult: System detects and displays the conflict within 2 seconds of booking submission

steps.action: Navigate to an existing booking and update it to create a resource over-allocation (assign more resources than available)
steps.expectedResult: Booking update is submitted successfully

steps.action: Monitor for conflict detection notification and measure response time
steps.expectedResult: Conflict is detected and logged promptly within 2 seconds, with notification displayed to the scheduler

steps.action: Access the conflict logs via the system interface or API endpoint GET /api/conflicts
steps.expectedResult: Conflict logs are accessible and displayed

steps.action: Verify that all conflicts from previous steps are recorded in the logs with accurate timestamps and relevant metadata (booking IDs, resource names, conflict type)
steps.expectedResult: All conflicts are recorded with correct timestamps showing detection within 2 seconds, including complete metadata for each conflict

postconditions: All test conflicts are logged in the system
No bookings are permanently saved with conflicts
System remains in operational state
Test data can be cleaned up or retained for audit

testCases.title: Test detection under concurrent scheduling inputs
preconditions: Multiple test user accounts with Scheduler role are available
Scheduling system is operational with adequate resources
Performance monitoring tools are configured and accessible
Test environment can simulate concurrent users
Baseline performance metrics are documented

steps.action: Set up simulation environment to create 5-10 concurrent scheduler sessions
steps.expectedResult: All concurrent sessions are established and authenticated successfully

steps.action: Simultaneously create multiple overlapping bookings from different scheduler sessions targeting the same resources and time slots
steps.expectedResult: All booking requests are submitted concurrently to the system

steps.action: Monitor each session for conflict detection notifications and record the detection time for each conflict
steps.expectedResult: System detects conflicts for all overlapping bookings without delay, all within 2 seconds of submission

steps.action: Access system performance metrics dashboard or API to retrieve detection latency measurements during the concurrent load
steps.expectedResult: Performance metrics are retrieved successfully showing individual detection times

steps.action: Analyze the performance data to verify that all conflict detections occurred within the 2-second threshold
steps.expectedResult: Detection latency remains under 2 seconds for all concurrent requests, with no performance degradation

steps.action: Review conflict logs to create a comprehensive list of all expected conflicts based on the concurrent bookings created
steps.expectedResult: Complete list of expected conflicts is compiled

steps.action: Cross-reference the conflict logs against the expected conflicts list to verify completeness
steps.expectedResult: All conflicts are identified accurately with no missed detections, 100% detection rate confirmed

postconditions: All concurrent test sessions are closed
System performance returns to baseline levels
All test conflicts are logged
Performance metrics are documented for future reference
Test bookings are cleaned up from the system

storyTitle: As Scheduler, I want to configure conflict detection rules to tailor alerts to my resource types

testCases.title: Validate rule configuration and application
preconditions: User is logged in with Scheduler role and appropriate permissions
Conflict rule configuration interface is accessible
At least two different resource types exist in the system
Current conflict detection rules are documented
System configuration database is operational

steps.action: Navigate to the conflict rule configuration interface via the system menu or direct URL
steps.expectedResult: Conflict rule configuration interface loads successfully

steps.action: Review the displayed current rules for all resource types, noting existing settings and thresholds
steps.expectedResult: Current rules are displayed clearly with all configured parameters visible including resource types, overlap thresholds, and enabled/disabled checks

steps.action: Select a specific resource type (e.g., Conference Room) and modify its rules with valid settings: set allowable overlap time to 15 minutes and enable buffer time check
steps.expectedResult: Rule modification interface accepts the changes and displays updated values

steps.action: Click the Save button to persist the rule changes
steps.expectedResult: System validates the rules, displays a success confirmation message, and rules are saved successfully

steps.action: Verify the saved rules by refreshing the configuration interface and checking that the modified settings persist
steps.expectedResult: Modified rules are displayed correctly showing the 15-minute overlap allowance and enabled buffer time check

steps.action: Attempt to create a new rule with invalid syntax (e.g., negative overlap time of -10 minutes)
steps.expectedResult: System displays validation error indicating invalid input

steps.action: Attempt to save conflicting rules (e.g., set minimum booking duration longer than maximum booking duration for the same resource type)
steps.expectedResult: System rejects the changes with a descriptive error message explaining the logical conflict between the rules

steps.action: Correct the invalid rules to valid settings and attempt to save again
steps.expectedResult: System accepts the corrected rules and saves them successfully with confirmation message

postconditions: Valid rule changes are persisted in the configuration database
Invalid rule attempts are rejected without affecting existing rules
System maintains data integrity
Audit log contains record of rule modification attempts

testCases.title: Verify detection engine applies updated rules
preconditions: User is logged in with Scheduler role
Conflict rule configuration interface is accessible
Conflict detection engine is running
At least one resource type with configurable rules exists
Booking creation interface is accessible

steps.action: Navigate to the conflict rule configuration interface and document the current rules for a specific resource type (e.g., Meeting Room)
steps.expectedResult: Current rules are displayed and documented, showing default settings

steps.action: Modify the conflict detection rules for Meeting Room resource type: set allowable overlap to 30 minutes and disable strict time slot enforcement
steps.expectedResult: Rule modifications are entered successfully

steps.action: Save the updated rules and note the exact timestamp of the save action
steps.expectedResult: System saves the rules successfully and displays confirmation with timestamp

steps.action: Wait and monitor the system status for up to 1 minute to allow rule propagation to the detection engine
steps.expectedResult: System indicates that rules are being applied or shows active status

steps.action: After 1 minute has elapsed, verify via system logs or admin interface that the updated rules have been applied to the detection engine
steps.expectedResult: Rules are applied to the detection engine within 1 minute of saving, confirmed by system logs or status indicators

steps.action: Navigate to the booking creation interface and create a new booking for a Meeting Room resource
steps.expectedResult: Booking creation form is displayed and ready for input

steps.action: Create a booking that overlaps with an existing Meeting Room booking by exactly 25 minutes (within the new 30-minute allowable overlap threshold)
steps.expectedResult: Booking is submitted successfully

steps.action: Observe the system response and check for conflict notifications
steps.expectedResult: No conflict is detected or alerted because the 25-minute overlap is within the configured 30-minute allowable threshold, demonstrating that updated rules are active

steps.action: Create another booking that overlaps by 35 minutes (exceeding the 30-minute threshold)
steps.expectedResult: Booking is submitted successfully

steps.action: Observe the system response for conflict detection
steps.expectedResult: Conflict is detected and notification is displayed because the 35-minute overlap exceeds the configured threshold, confirming conflict detection behaves according to updated rules

postconditions: Updated rules are active in the detection engine
Conflict detection behaves according to new rule parameters
Test bookings demonstrate rule application
System logs reflect rule changes and detection behavior
Test bookings can be removed or retained for further testing

storyTitle: As Scheduler, I want the system to log all detected conflicts with timestamps and metadata for audit and analysis

testCases.title: Verify logging of detected conflicts with metadata
preconditions: User has authorized access to the conflict logging system
Conflict detection engine is running and operational
Centralized logging database is accessible and has sufficient storage
API endpoint GET /api/conflict-logs is available
At least two bookings exist that can create a conflict scenario
Detection rule version is configured and active

steps.action: Create two overlapping bookings for the same resource to trigger a conflict detection event
steps.expectedResult: Conflict is detected by the system and conflict detection engine processes the event

steps.action: Verify that the conflict is logged automatically by checking the logging service status
steps.expectedResult: Logging service confirms that the conflict event has been recorded with a unique log entry ID

steps.action: Check that the log entry contains an accurate timestamp of when the conflict was detected
steps.expectedResult: Timestamp is present in ISO 8601 format and matches the time of conflict detection within acceptable margin (Â±1 second)

steps.action: Verify that the log entry includes metadata for involved bookings (booking IDs, booking times, user information)
steps.expectedResult: All involved booking IDs are present with complete booking details including start time, end time, and associated user information

steps.action: Verify that the log entry includes resource information (resource ID, resource name, resource type)
steps.expectedResult: Complete resource details are logged including resource ID, name, and type

steps.action: Verify that the detection rule version used is recorded in the log entry
steps.expectedResult: Detection rule version number is present and matches the currently active rule version

steps.action: Send a GET request to /api/conflict-logs endpoint with appropriate authentication credentials
steps.expectedResult: API responds with HTTP 200 status code and returns the conflict log data

steps.action: Query the logs using the conflict ID or timestamp to retrieve the specific log entry created in previous steps
steps.expectedResult: Log entry is successfully retrieved with all complete details including timestamp, booking IDs, resource information, and detection rule version

steps.action: Verify that the retrieved log entry matches the expected data structure and contains all required fields
steps.expectedResult: Log entry contains all mandatory fields: conflict_id, timestamp, involved_bookings[], resources[], detection_rule_version, conflict_type, and status

steps.action: Initiate an export operation for the conflict logs through the API or UI, specifying the desired format (CSV, JSON, or XML)
steps.expectedResult: Export request is accepted and processing begins

steps.action: Download or retrieve the exported log file
steps.expectedResult: Logs are successfully exported in the requested format with all data intact and properly formatted

steps.action: Open and verify the exported file contains the conflict log entry with all metadata
steps.expectedResult: Exported file is readable, contains the logged conflict with complete metadata, and data integrity is maintained

postconditions: Conflict log entry remains stored in the centralized database
Log entry is available for future queries and audits
Exported log file is saved and accessible for analysis
No data corruption or loss occurred during logging or export process
System resources are released and logging service is ready for next event

testCases.title: Ensure logging does not impact detection performance
preconditions: Conflict detection engine is operational with logging enabled
Performance monitoring tools are configured and ready
Baseline performance metrics are established
Test environment has representative load conditions
System has sufficient resources (CPU, memory, disk I/O)
Ability to enable/disable logging feature for comparison testing
Multiple test conflict scenarios are prepared for consistent testing

steps.action: Ensure that the logging feature is enabled in the system configuration
steps.expectedResult: Logging feature status is confirmed as enabled through system settings or configuration file

steps.action: Prepare a set of 10 conflict scenarios with overlapping bookings to ensure consistent testing conditions
steps.expectedResult: Test data is ready with 10 predefined conflict scenarios that can be triggered repeatedly

steps.action: Clear any existing performance metrics and reset monitoring tools to baseline
steps.expectedResult: Performance monitoring tools are reset and ready to capture fresh metrics

steps.action: Trigger the first conflict detection scenario and start measuring the detection latency from conflict occurrence to detection completion
steps.expectedResult: Conflict is detected and latency measurement is recorded

steps.action: Repeat the conflict detection process for all 10 prepared scenarios while recording latency for each detection
steps.expectedResult: All 10 conflicts are detected and individual latency measurements are captured

steps.action: Calculate the average detection latency with logging enabled across all 10 test runs
steps.expectedResult: Average detection latency is calculated and documented (e.g., 1.2 seconds)

steps.action: Verify that the average detection latency with logging enabled remains within the acceptable threshold of 2 seconds
steps.expectedResult: Average latency is at or below 2 seconds, meeting the performance requirement

steps.action: Verify that individual detection latencies do not exceed 2 seconds for any single test run
steps.expectedResult: All individual latency measurements are within the 2-second threshold

steps.action: Disable the logging feature in the system configuration
steps.expectedResult: Logging feature is successfully disabled and confirmed through system settings

steps.action: Clear performance metrics and reset monitoring tools again for the second test phase
steps.expectedResult: Monitoring tools are reset and ready for the next measurement phase

steps.action: Trigger the same 10 conflict detection scenarios used previously and measure detection latency without logging
steps.expectedResult: All 10 conflicts are detected and latency measurements are captured without logging overhead

steps.action: Calculate the average detection latency with logging disabled across all 10 test runs
steps.expectedResult: Average detection latency without logging is calculated and documented (e.g., 1.1 seconds)

steps.action: Compare the average detection latency with logging enabled versus logging disabled
steps.expectedResult: Difference in average latency is calculated (e.g., 0.1 seconds difference)

steps.action: Verify that the performance difference between logging enabled and disabled is not significant (less than 10% degradation or less than 200ms absolute difference)
steps.expectedResult: Performance impact is minimal and within acceptable limits, confirming that logging does not significantly degrade detection performance

steps.action: Document the performance test results including both average latencies and the percentage difference
steps.expectedResult: Complete performance report is generated showing that logging has no measurable negative impact on conflict detection performance

postconditions: Logging feature is re-enabled to operational state
Performance metrics are documented and stored for future reference
System performance remains within acceptable parameters
No performance degradation is observed in conflict detection
Test data and scenarios are preserved for regression testing
Performance baseline is updated if necessary
